Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: I was encouraged to come here by @Slyris. Sorry if this has already been asked, but why pick DPoW over a token when a token on Ethereum represents a much more decentralized, and arguably more secure, solution? You can already pay gas fees in tokens via work on gas stations. My only other thought is the speed offered by a native chain, but of course you can always pick an Ethereum altchain/sidechain, although I admit that reduces security.

Author: ComputerGenie 游놊游낖游닉#7004
Content:
`a token on Ethereum represents a much more decentralized...solution`
By what metric is it true that being tied to the codebase of a parent chain is more decentralized than creating your own chain that does whatever you want it to do and follows whatever rules you want?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you like paying $5 per transaction and can ignore being 100% at the mercy of the underlying chain, then certainly, just use ERC20

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: @ComputerGenie 游놊游낖游닉 I was referring to Ethereum nodes compared to Komodo... what's the term?

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Notary

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe there are tricks that automatically convert your ERC20 token into ETH to pay for gas, but still you are paying 100x to 10000x the cost per transaction.

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: So transaction fees and the fact you have your own codebase.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also, this is not dPoS it is dPoW on top of PoW

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the consensus is fully decentralized, dPoW submits proposed notarizations and each node verifies if it is valid or not.

Author: ComputerGenie 游놊游낖游닉#7004
Content:
`I was referring to Ethereum nodes compared to Komodo... what's the term? Notary`
Notary nodes validate your chain by your rules and create the equivalent of a live checkpoints
They don't control your chain in any way that you don't agree with

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: I'm not calling dPoW centralized. I'm saying Ethereum has more nodes participating (unless Komodo nodes have increased by a massive count).

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i heard ETH was proposing using decentralized checkpoints

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: @ComputerGenie 游놊游낖游닉 I understand how checkpoints work.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how many full nodes does ETH have now?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i would imagine KMD has more

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, so it is comparable

Author: ComputerGenie 游놊游낖游닉#7004
Content: more nodes participating does not always mean more people

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: @jl777c Have a link to Komodo node counts?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: <https://komodostats.com/ecomap>

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: 6568, thanks

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Closer than I thought

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: And then just to double check, dPoW costs money as it's a service, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but if you are not cost sensitive, then just use ERC20, how much can $5 per tx add up to anyway

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: So an independent chain saves the 70 cent ERC20 transfer, plus an extra dollar or so for a gas station, yet charges the developers more.

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: $5 is really out of touch with the current state of Ethereum.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: until the costs do go up again, unpredictably

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: That is fair, so my question becomes how are DPoW costs calculated?

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: If it's in BTC, there's the exact same issue.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: why?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the BTC costs are not passed through

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: KMD absorbs the BTC costs, regardless of BTC price

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: I didn't meant the cost to run DPoW; I meant the cost to use it

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: That's good to hear. So what is the pricing model?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i dont have the exact pricing, you need to contact the service provider for that, but it is a fixed cost model

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Eh. I can probably google it. No need to ask 游뗵

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Thanks for the info on that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think if you expect to do more than 10 transactions per day, that is around the breakeven point. if less than 10 tx per day, then just use ERC20

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: i don't think you will get the price by googling it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW only makes sense for projects that create coins that will be used

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Of course if the coin achieves great usage, it's possible they won't need the additional security, although more security is better

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 100 tx per day is less than 1 tx every 10 blocks, not exactly great amount of usage

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yet, already the cost is approx 10x higher for the ERC20

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Alrighty. Then if you have some time, I'm also curious your stance on PoS for speed, for security, and for distribution.

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: But I did already ask a question

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: PoS is not as good as PoW

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it is more energy efficient

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: speed wise, you can get basically the same speed with PoW or PoS

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: distribution is much better with PoW as with PoS, distribution basically stops

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: My main interest with speed is a vote system, not a mining system. I agree PoW mining is as fast as PoS staking to generate blocks.

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Happy to hear you say that about security/distribution though.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: security... well that will start an endless debate. lets just say that there are much fewer attack vectors against PoW and with dPoW i feel there is not much exposure, just some miners can get higher ROI with on/off mining

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with PoW a chain that isnt the highest hashrate for that algo, or sometimes even if it is, can be nicehashed

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: I think most people argue PoS stops massive accumulation in an instant, but it does amplify existing whales.

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: I will concede I see much fewer PoS chains reorged

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the 51% becomes very real. with dPoW and using dpowconfs, we dont know of any way to conduct a 51% attack, and after the notarization, it becomes immutable

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a big buy wall on an exchange allows for massive accumulation independent of PoW or PoS, also a lot of PoS devolves to PoW

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: PoW is just a much simpler way and i wouldnt be surprised to read about some news that a major PoS chain is successfully attacked someday. i also wouldnt be surprised if i dont see that news, so it is not a certain thing, just a possibility

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Yeah. It's a lot harder to track especially when the whales/services who would notice generally have a noticeable stake to protect.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just understanding how stake grinding is possible with some PoS algos, it is quite complex

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: My personal work is on hybridization of the two so I was curious your overall thoughts.

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: It's always possible :/ Every single PoS algo has had a stake grinding vuln

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: As soon as they say it's fixed, another one pops up. PIVX said they've known about the most recent one for months and will fix it in half an year :/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and impossible to prove a negative, so we just need to hope that there is no exploit

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: It's almost like whales don't care to fix bugs benefitting whales

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Though I think they said that about half an year agoso it may be fixed soon

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with PoW, there is none of that, just the 51%, which dPoW solves

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: What about PoS voting though?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: original peercoin staking algo was just very prone to stake grinding, so the evolution of it... carries on the tradition

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: KMD uses PoS voting to elect notary nodes

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: That's generally the system looked at for speed since it doesn't require batching into blocks and there's no difficulty algorithm delaying the block artifically

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Yep, I saw that.

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: I was honestly surprised you didn't go with a weighted random function.

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: But I'm not an expert on it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: lottery for election?

Author: Kayaba#5184
Content: Similar to some existing PoS systems
